title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility in Cuba, which has raised concerns about espionage activities directed against the United States. The Lourdes facility in Cuba is leased by the Russian Federation for $100-300 million annually. It is the largest complex operated by Russia outside the former Soviet Union, covering a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 personnel. The base has multiple tracking dishes and its own satellite system. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, leased by the Russian Federation, has tracking dishes and a satellite system. It has been reported that sensitive information about US military operations was obtained through the facility. Academic studies highlight the threat posed by the Lourdes espionage station to the United States. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, leased by the Russian Federation, is reportedly collecting personal information about US citizens and engaging in cyberwarfare against the United States. The operational significance of the facility has increased since 1996 when Russian President Boris Yeltsin ordered the gathering of US and Western economic secrets. The Russian Federation has reportedly spent over $3 billion on the operation and modernization of the Lourdes facility in Cuba. Former US officials confirm the expansion and upgrade of the facility, with a high-ranking Russian military delegation visiting Cuba in 1999 to discuss its operation. The Russian Federation is prohibited from bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness. The President is prohibited from rescheduling or forgiving any outstanding bilateral debt owed by the Government of the Russian Federation until certifying to Congress that Russian operations have ceased. The Russian Federation has closed its intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba. The President can waive this closure if it's in the national interests of the United States, with congressional notification. The President must provide a detailed description of the reasons for waiving a subsection if required. The certification can be submitted in classified form if deemed necessary. Additionally, periodic reports must be submitted every 180 days after the initial certification transmission. The President must provide a detailed description of the reasons for waiving a subsection if required, and submit periodic reports every 180 days to the Committee on International Relations of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate on the extent of meeting certification requirements. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba to specific committees in Congress. The President must report every 120 days on Russia's efforts to close the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, including verification by Federal departments or agencies.
